SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).

C.Choice: by breaking down the different kinds of life on Earth into different categories

D.Choice: by showing how many more microbes there are on Earth than there are humans

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: In Passage 2, what is the effect of comparing the number of microbes to the human population and the number of stars in the Milky Way?

A.Choice: It shows readers how small microbial populations are.

B.Choice: It provides context for how large microbial populations are.

C.Choice: It describes ways to count the total population of microbes.

D.Choice: It illustrates that microbial populations cannot be estimated.

SubTopics: Analyze a case in which two or more texts provide conflicting information on the same topic and identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.
Content: How is the treatment of the topic of microbes different in Passage 1 and Passage 2?

A.Choice: Passage 1 shows how microbes appear in a laboratory environment; Passage 2 describes how microbes reproduce in the natural environment.

B.Choice: Passage 1 reveals how our knowledge of microbes was limited; Passage 2 suggests how our knowledge of microbes has expanded in recent years.

C.Choice: Passage 1 explains a milestone in scientific understanding of microbes; Passage 2 emphasizes the early existence and astounding number of microbes in the environment.

D.Choice: Passage 1 demonstrates how the scientific community hindered our understanding of microbes; Passage 2 suggests that mathematical formulas can increase our understanding of microbes.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas

Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 3.

B.Choice: Ventriloquists focus the attention of the audience to conceal the source of a sound.

C.Choice: Ventriloquists start with a single puppet to engage the audience with its sound.

D.Choice: Sounds travel through the air to stimulate the senses.

Content: Based on the passage, what are ğ—§ğ—ªğ—¢ ways ventriloquists make their puppets seem real? Select ğ—§ğ—ªğ—¢ answers.

A.Choice: by using the same voice for the various puppets used in the show

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which choice provides the ğ—•ğ—˜ğ—¦ğ—§ objective summary of the passage?

A.Choice: Ventriloquists use scientific data to create humorous illusions onstage. Scientists have found that certain parts of the brain are able to process both sight and sound at the same time.

B.Choice: Ventriloquism is about balancing art and science in a show. I think all ventriloquists are talented at performing funny shows and can often get away with making statements that are odd.

C.Choice: Ventriloquism works due to the science behind sound. Because of the way people process sound, ventriloquists use a variety of techniques in their art to create convincing illusions.

D.Choice: Ventriloquists rely on scientists to create their illusions. Researchers and artists come together to make shows that are more entertaining than most other types of live performances.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.

D.Choice: by explaining an opinion and showing how it was shaped by personal experiences

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

D.Choice: â€œThe eldest observed that the trees were like nothing he had ever seen.â€

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: In Passage 1, paragraphs 7 and 21 reveal na importantly difference between the brothers ğ— ğ—”ğ—œğ—¡ğ—Ÿğ—¬

A.Choice: by suggesting that the eldest brother will continue on his journey, while Sadaka will return home sooner than planned.

B.Choice: by showing how the eldest brother must decide alone what to do with the seeds, while Sadaka can go to the jinns for advice.

C.Choice: by emphasizing that the eldest brother thinks of the fruit as nourishment too, while Sadaka is more interested in its taste.

D.Choice: by showing how the eldest brother assumes he can use the seeds to benefit himself, while Sadaka wants to learn more about them.

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.

Content: In Passage 1, how does the author create suspense in Sadaka's first meeting with the prince?

A.Choice: The reader knows the prince will follow through with his threat to imprison Sadaka, but Sadaka does not believe him.

B.Choice: The reader knows the man the prince has imprisoned is Sadaka's brother, but Sadaka is not aware of this.

C.Choice: The reader worries that Sadaka will be tricked by the prince, but Sadaka trusts they will become friends.

D.Choice: The reader wonders if the jinns' special soil will work, but Sadaka is certain that it will.

Content: Which choice provides the ğ—•ğ—˜ğ—¦ğ—§ evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: â€œThey gave Sadaka the soil he would need, and Sadaka again set sail.â€

B.Choice: â€œSadaka met the formidable prince and told him of the fruit.â€

C.Choice: â€œIf your story proves false, just like him, you shall be imprisoned.â€

D.Choice: â€œYou are fortunate, my friend. However, you have one more test.â€

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: What is the theme in Passage 1?

A.Choice: If you travel too far away from home, bad luck may follow you.

B.Choice: Be wary when placing your trust in things that seem too good to be true.

C.Choice: If you take time to help others, they will likely help you in times of trouble.

D.Choice: Close family members are the only people you can rely on when you need help.

SubTopics: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.
Content: Now read the writing task and draft a response. As you write, think about what makes writing successful.
problems/NMG8E/media/33a.jpg

:box:You have read three articles about the Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The articles include information about tourism and its effects on the state, the caverns, and the caverns' ecosystem. Having read about tourism at the Carlsbad Caverns National Park, take a position about whether the Carlsbad Caverns should remain open for tourism.

You decide to write an argumentative letter to the editor of your local newspaper in which you present your argument and state your position about whether the Carlsbad Caverns should remain open for tourism. Use details and examples from the articles, along with your own ideas and experience, to support your claim and position.

:ibox:Today you will be writing an argument. When you write an argument, you

â€¢ make and support a claim based on factual evidence.
â€¢ gather and present reasons for making that claim.
â€¢ use specific facts, examples, and details to support and elaborate upon those reasons.

After you have read the passages, and before you begin writing, think about

â€¢ what evidence in the passages leads you to make your claim about whether the Carlsbad Caverns National Park should remain open for tourists.
â€¢ what you already know and what fact-based evidence you have to support your claim about whether the Carlsbad Caverns should remain open for tourism.
â€¢ how you might address evidence that supports a different idea or position.

Now write your response in the space provided.
